item.title: AoC 2025 Day 12: Knapsackinator
item.description:
Source: Day 12: Christmas Tree Farm

Full solution for today (spoilers!).

  • Source: Day 12: Christmas Tree Farm
  • Part 1
  • Part 1 - It’s actually trivial
  • Rendering
  • Benchmarks

Part 1

Solve the knapsack problem.

…

…

But really, you are given a set of tiles (which all happen to be some subset of a 3x3) and a set of constraints–a MxN grid and how many of each tile to place. Count how many constraints are possible.

Tiles may be rotated and/or flipped.

Part 1

Given a directed graph defined where aaa: you hhh means aaa is connected to you and hhh, how many paths are there from you to out.

item.title: AoC 2025 Day 10: Linear Algebranator
item.description:
Source: Day 10: Factory

Full solution for today (spoilers!).

  • Source: Day 10: Factory
  • Part 1
  • Part 2
  • Part 2 - A system of equations [WIP]
  • Part 2 - Memoization
  • Part 2 - Add branch and bound
  • Part 2 - Just use z3
  • [12/11] Part 2 - Equations continued
  • Benchmarks

Part 1

Given a target light pattern [.##.] and a series of buttons ((3) (1, 3) etc) where the first button toggles light ‘3’ (the 4th light) and the second toggles the first and 4th etc, what is the minimum number of buttons you need to press to match the light pattern.

item.title: AoC 2024 Day 23: LAN Partinator
item.description:
Source: Day 23: LAN Party

Full solution for today (spoilers!).

  • Source: Day 23: LAN Party
  • Part 1
  • Part 2
    • Corrected version 1: Largest completely connected
    • Corrected version 2: Recursion + memoization
    • Corrected version 3: Ordering by most connected nodes
    • This is stupid…
    • …and complicated
  • Benchmarks

Part 1

You are given the edges of an undirected graph. Count how many complete subgraphs of size three exist that contain one or more starting with the letter t.

Aside: Games with local (but not hotseat) multiplayer have gotten rather rarer over the years… how many people still know what a LAN party is/was?

item.title: AoC 2024 Day 21: Busy Workinator
item.description:
Source: Day 21: Keypad Conundrum

Full solution for today (spoilers!).

  • Source: Day 21: Keypad Conundrum
  • Part 1
    • (Failed) Version 1: Way over engineered
    • Version 2: Direct simulation
  • Part 2
    • Memoization
  • Benchmarks
    • Tracing

Part 1

You are trying to type a code on a keypad:

+---+---+---+
| 7 | 8 | 9 |
+---+---+---+
| 4 | 5 | 6 |
+---+---+---+
| 1 | 2 | 3 |
+---+---+---+
 | 0 | A |
 +---+---+

But you cannot type directly. Instead, you can control a pointer on the keypad with arrow keys:

 +---+---+
 | ^ | A |
+---+---+---+
| < | v | > |
+---+---+---+

Whenever you type a ^ on the arrow keys, the pointer on the keypad will move up one, etc. When you type A, then the pointer on the keypad will type whatever it is pointing at.

But that’s not enough either. Add a second keypad. And then a third, that is the one you are actually controlling.

For each output sequence multiple the length of the minimum input sequence needed to generate it by the numeric value of the input sequence (ignoring any A); sum these.

Note: Moving off any keypad or into the blank spaces is an error.

Given a comma delimited list of substrings and a list of strings, count how many of the latter strings can be made up of any (repeating) combination of the former.

item.title: AoC 2024 Day 11: Exponential Growthinator
item.description:
Source: Day 11: Plutonian Pebbles

Full solution for today (spoilers!).

  • Source: Day 11: Plutonian Pebbles
  • Part 1
    • Optimization 1: Recursion
    • Optimization 2: Memoization
  • Part 2
    • Optimization (attempt) 3: Association list cache
    • Optimization (attempt) 4: BTree cache
    • Optimization 5: Iterate over HashMap<value, count>
  • Benchmarks

Part 1

Given a sequence of values v_n, replace each value with the first matching rule:

  • if v = 0 -> 1
  • If v has an even number of digits, split it (so v = 8675 becomes [86, 75])
  • Otherwise, v -> v * 2024

Calculate how many elements are in the sequence after 25 iterations.

Part 1

Given a result and a list of numbers, determine if any combination of addition (+) and/or multiplication (*) using all the given numbers in order can return the result. Ignore order of operations.

item.title: StackLang Part VII: New CLI and Datatypes
item.description:
Another day, another Stacklang!

Posts in StackLang:

  • StackLang Part IX: Better Testing
  • StackLang Part VIII: Compiler Stacks
  • StackLang Part VII: New CLI and Datatypes
  • StackLang Part VI: Some Examples
  • StackLang Part V: Compiling to C
  • StackLang Part IV: An Interpreter
  • StackLang Part III: The Parser
  • StackLang Part II: The Lexer
  • StackLang Part I: The Idea

Today, we’ve got two main parts to work on:
